page.title: 02CONSERVATION
page.content: IN THE HORSFORD AND FELTHORPE AREA WE HAVE FIELDS,WOODS,ROADS,FOOTPATHS AND HOUSES.OF THESE,MOST IS WOODLAND AND FIELD ALMOST ENTIRELY ALTERED FROM ITS NATURAL STATE BY MAN'S ACTIVITIES. THE EXPECTED PATTERN OF GRASS AND WOODLAND PLANTS AND ANIMALS IS MUCH CHANGED. EVEN HEDGES, ONE OF THE LAST REFUGES OF NATIVE ANIMALS, ARE DISAPPEARING FROM THE AREA,AS FENCES BECOME PREDOMINANT.THE FEW REMAINING WOODLAND DEER ARE DISTURBED BY MAN,INSECTS ARE DECIMATED BY AGRICULTURAL INSECTICIDES NATURAL WOODLAND HAS BEEN SUCCEEDED BY PLANTED CONIFERS.THE LOSS OF ONE PLANT OR ANIMAL COMMUNITY HAS CHAIN EFFECT ON OTHERS.BIRDS,FOR EXAMPLE, ARE SUFFERING FROM A GENERAL DECLINE IN POPULATION. IN SUMMARY,SOME PLANTS AND ANIMALS ARE BEING SELECTIVELY ENCOURAGED, WHILE OTHERS BECOME FEWER.
